title: Update UI color palette to navy/slate/gold across navigation, buttons, dashboard cards, and badges

requirements.text:
Replace the app’s existing primary branding color (#43587A) with the new palette by updating the global theme/color variables so that:
- Primary = #003057 (navy blue)
- Secondary = #5B8FA3 (slate blue)
- Accent = #F4A82E (gold/yellow)
- Text on dark backgrounds = #FFFFFF (white)
- Neutral gray = #A8A9AD (light gray)
This must be applied via the project’s existing Tailwind/OKLCH CSS variable approach (not inline per-component hex colors).

quotes:
Replace the current primary color (#43587A) with these new colors:
   - Primary (main buttons, navigation active state): #003057 (navy blue)
   - Secondary (accents, hover states): #5B8FA3 (slate blue)
   - Accent (highlights, badges): #F4A82E (gold/yellow)
   - Text on dark backgrounds: #FFFFFF (white)
   - Neutral gray: #A8A9AD (light gray)

acceptanceCriteria: Global theme variables in frontend/src/index.css are updated to reflect the new palette, using OKLCH variables consistent with the existing implementation.
Any existing references to the old brand color variable (e.g., --theiarco-primary and any derived utilities) now render as the new primary navy (#003057).
No layout changes occur; only colors change across the app.

requirements.text: Update the header/navigation styling so the header background uses the new primary navy (#003057) and all header text/icons maintain readable contrast (white on navy where applicable), while keeping the header layout and behavior unchanged.

quotes: Keep all layouts and functionality the same - only update colors.
Make sure text remains readable with good contrast on all backgrounds.

acceptanceCriteria: The header bar uses the navy primary as its background color.
Header title and controls remain readable (sufficient contrast) against the navy background.
Header spacing, height, and interactions (menu toggle, logout) are unchanged.

requirements.text: Update the sidebar active navigation item colors so the active item background is the new primary navy (#003057) and active text/icon color remains readable (white on navy), without changing sidebar layout or navigation behavior.

quotes: Sidebar active item background: navy blue
Primary (main buttons, navigation active state): #003057 (navy blue)

acceptanceCriteria: Active sidebar link background renders as #003057 (via existing utility/variable approach).
Active sidebar link text/icons render with readable contrast (white on navy).
Hover/inactive styles remain functionally the same, only color-adjusted to fit the new palette.

requirements.text: Update primary buttons throughout the app so their primary styling (e.g., main action buttons such as “Add Publisher”, “Record Visit”, etc.) uses the new primary navy (#003057), with hover/focus/active states using complementary shades aligned to the new palette (including using #5B8FA3 where appropriate), while preserving all existing button sizes, variants, and behavior.

quotes: Primary buttons (Add Publisher, Record Visit, etc.): navy blue

acceptanceCriteria: Primary button backgrounds render as #003057 and text remains readable (white on navy where applicable).
Hover/focus/active states are updated to complementary palette shades and remain visually distinct from the default state.
No button functionality, placement, or sizing changes occur.

requirements.text: Update the Dashboard stat card colors to use a combination of the new navy (#003057), slate (#5B8FA3), and gold (#F4A82E) while preserving the existing stat card layout, typography, and interactions (including hover effects). Keep existing non-stat alert colors (e.g., overdue red/orange) functionally consistent but harmonize with the new palette where those colors are controlled by theme variables.

quotes: Stat cards on dashboard: use navy blue, slate blue, gold combinations
Keep all layouts and functionality the same - only update colors.

acceptanceCriteria: Dashboard stat cards that currently use custom CSS variables (e.g., bg-dashboard-stat-*) are updated so their backgrounds reflect the new navy/slate/gold palette.
Stat card text remains readable (good contrast) on the updated backgrounds.
Card layout, counts, labels, and link behavior remain unchanged.

requirements.text: Adjust status badge color shades (green/red/orange) across the app to better complement the new navy/slate/gold palette while keeping the same semantic meanings (e.g., success/on-track stays green, destructive/behind stays red, warning stays orange) and ensuring readable contrast between badge text and badge backgrounds.

quotes: Badge colors for status can stay green/red/orange but adjust shades to complement the new palette
Make sure text remains readable with good contrast on all backgrounds.

acceptanceCriteria: Status badges still appear green/red/orange by meaning, but their shades are adjusted to look cohesive with the new palette.
Badge text remains readable on each badge background in both light and dark modes (where applicable).
No badge wording or logic changes occur (only styling).

requirements.text: Verify and enforce readable contrast across the updated palette in both light and dark themes by updating theme foreground/foreground-on-color variables (e.g., primary-foreground, secondary-foreground, accent-foreground, muted-foreground, and any brand-specific foreground usage) so that text/icons are legible on their respective backgrounds.

quotes: Make sure text remains readable with good contrast on all backgrounds.

acceptanceCriteria: Text on navy backgrounds renders as white (#FFFFFF) where intended and remains legible.
Accent (gold) usage does not reduce readability of overlaid text; foreground values are adjusted accordingly.
No new UI regressions where text becomes low-contrast due to palette changes.

constraints: Keep all layouts and functionality unchanged; only update colors.
Do not modify files under frontend/src/components/ui (compose them via theme/variables instead).
Do not edit immutable paths listed in SYSTEM_CONTEXT (e.g., frontend/src/main.tsx and auth/actor hooks).
nonGoals: Adding new pages, routes, or features.
Changing wording/copy, component structure, spacing, or app behavior.
Backend changes (Motoko actor logic/state) or migrations.
